<script type="text/javascript">
var PREBID_TIMEOUT = 300;
var googletag = googletag || {};
googletag.cmd = googletag.cmd || [];
(function (){
    window.advBidxc = window.advBidxc || {};
    window.advBidxc.renderAd = function (){};
    window.advBidxc.startTime = new Date().getTime();
    function loadScript(tagSrc) {
        if (tagSrc.substr(0, 4) !== 'http') {
            var isSSL = 'https:' == document.location.protocol;
            tagSrc = (isSSL ? 'https:' : 'http:') + tagSrc;
        }   
        var scriptTag = document.createElement('script'),
            placeTag = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
        scriptTag.type = 'text/javascript';
        scriptTag.async = true;
        scriptTag.src = tagSrc;
        placeTag.parentNode.insertBefore(scriptTag, placeTag);
    }
    function loadGPT(){
        if(!window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded){
            loadScript('//www.googletagservices.com/tag/js/gpt.js');
            window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded = true;
        }
    }

    window.advBidxc.loadGPT = loadGPT;
    setTimeout(window.advBidxc.loadGPT,PREBID_TIMEOUT);// Timeout in case of loading error
    var mnSrc = ('https:' == document.location.protocol ? 'https:' : 'http:') + '//contextual.media.net/bidexchange.js?cid=8CU2553YN';

})();

        <div id="story-meta" class="story-meta story-meta-theme-white">
                                    			<h1 id="story-heading" class="story-heading balance-text">ISIS Enshrines a Theology of Rape</h1>
		<p itemprop="headline" id="story-deck" class="deck balance-text">Claiming the Quran’s support, the Islamic State codifies sex slavery in conquered regions of Iraq and Syria and uses the practice as a recruiting tool.</p>
	                        <div id="story-meta-footer" class="story-meta-footer">
                                                                                    

<p class="byline-dateline"><span class="byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"  itemid="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/c/rukmini_callimachi/index.html">By <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/c/rukmini_callimachi/index.html" rel="author" title="More Articles by RUKMINI CALLIMACHI"><span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="RUKMINI CALLIMACHI" itemprop="name">RUKMINI CALLIMACHI</span></a></span><time class="dateline" datetime="2015-08-13" itemprop="datePublished" content="2015-08-13">AUG. 13, 2015</time>
</p>
                                    <div class="inside-story">
                        <span class="menu-label">Inside</span>
                        <ul class="inside-story-menu"></ul>
                    </div>

        </div><!-- close story-meta -->

        <p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="326" data-total-count="326" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-1">QADIYA, Iraq — In the moments before he raped the 12-year-old girl, the Islamic State fighter took the time to explain that what he was about to do was not a sin. Because the preteen girl practiced a religion other than Islam, the Quran not only gave him the right to rape her — it condoned and encouraged it, he insisted.</p><aside id='middle-right-paid-post-container' class='ad middle-right-ad paid-post-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent'>
                                <h2 class='marginalia-heading'></h2>
                                    <ul class='story-menu'>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost1' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost2' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost3' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost4' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                    </ul>
                                </aside><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="126" data-total-count="452" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-2">He bound her hands and gagged her. Then he knelt beside the bed and prostrated himself in prayer before getting on top of her.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="94" data-total-count="546" itemprop="articleBody">When it was over, he knelt to pray again, bookending the rape with acts of religious devotion.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="391" data-total-count="937" itemprop="articleBody">“I kept telling him it hurts — please stop,” said the girl, whose body is so small an adult could circle her waist with two hands. “He told me that according to Islam he is allowed to rape an unbeliever. He said that by raping me, he is drawing closer to God,” she said in an interview alongside her family in a refugee camp here, to which she escaped after 11 months of captivity.</p>    <aside class="marginalia related-coverage-marginalia nocontent robots-nocontent" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" role="complementary" module="RelatedCoverage-Marginalia">
        <div class="nocontent robots-nocontent">
            <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-3">Continue reading the main story</a>

                                                                                <li><article class="story theme-summary">
    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/14/insider/kidnapping-and-sex-slavery-covering-isiss-religious-justification-for-rape.html">

                    <div class="thumb">
                <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/16/insider/isis-slave/isis-slave-thumbStandard-v3.jpg" alt="Aishan Ali Saleh, 40, at a refugee camp. She had lived in Kojo, one of the southernmost villages on Mount Sinjar, which was overrun by Islamic State fighters." />
                <div class="media-action-overlay"></div>
            </div>
        
        <h2 class="story-heading">
                        <span class="story-heading-text">Kidnapping and Sex Slavery: Covering ISIS’ Religious Justification for Rape</span><time class="dateline" datetime="2015-08-14" itemprop="datePublished" content="2015-08-14">AUG. 14, 2015</time>
        </h2>

    </a>
</article>
</li>
                                                </ul>
        </div><!-- close nocontent -->
    </aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="467" data-total-count="1404" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-3">The systematic rape of women and girls from the Yazidi religious minority has become deeply enmeshed in the organization and the radical theology of the Islamic State in the year since the group announced it was reviving slavery as an institution. Interviews with 21 women and girls who recently escaped the Islamic State, as well as an examination of the group’s official communications, illuminate how the practice has been enshrined in the group’s core tenets.</p><figure id="isisslave-series-box" class="interactive interactive-embedded  has-adjacency has-lede-adjacency limit-small layout-small">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-4">Continue reading the main story</a>

    
    <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
            <h2 class="interactive-headline">
            State of Terror        </h2>
                <p class="interactive-leadin">
            Articles in this series examine the rise of the Islamic State and life inside the territory it has conquered.        </p>
        </figcaption>

        <div class="interactive-graphic">
        <script>function getFlexData() { return {"data":{"config":{"title":{},"summary":{}},"items":{"item":{"kicker":{},"head":{},"link":{},"pub_date":{},"thumb":{}}}}}; }var NYTD=NYTD || {}; NYTD.FlexTypes = NYTD.FlexTypes || []; NYTD.FlexTypes.push({"target":"FT100000003851310","type":"Series Box","data":{"config":{"title":{},"summary":{}},"items":{"item":{"kicker":{},"head":{},"link":{},"pub_date":{},"thumb":{}}}}});</script><link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/js/nytdesign/2014/flextypes/sbox.css" />
<!--div id="nytd-sbox">
	<h6 id="nytd-series-headline" class="kicker"></h6>
	<p id="nytd-series-summary" class="summary"></p>
	<ul id="nytd-series-list"></ul>
</div-->
<script type="text/javascript" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/js/nytdesign/2014/flextypes/sbox.js"></script><div id="FT100000003851310"></div>    </div>
    
    <div class="footer">

        
        
        
    </div>
</figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="241" data-total-count="1645" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-4">The trade in Yazidi women and girls has created a persistent infrastructure, with a network of warehouses where the victims are held, viewing rooms where they are inspected and marketed, and a dedicated fleet of buses used to transport them.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="442" data-total-count="2087" itemprop="articleBody">A total of 5,270 Yazidis were abducted last year, and at least 3,144 are still being held, according to community leaders. To handle them, the Islamic State has developed a detailed bureaucracy of sex slavery, including sales contracts notarized by the ISIS-run Islamic courts. And the practice has become an established recruiting tool to lure men from deeply conservative Muslim societies, where casual sex is taboo and dating is forbidden.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="461" data-total-count="2548" itemprop="articleBody">A growing body of internal policy memos and theological discussions has established guidelines for slavery, including a lengthy how-to manual issued by the Islamic State Research and Fatwa Department just last month. Repeatedly, the <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/18/world/europe/jihad-and-girl-power-how-isis-lured-3-london-teenagers.html">ISIS</a> leadership has emphasized a narrow and selective reading of the Quran and other religious rulings to not only justify violence, but also to elevate and celebrate each sexual assault as spiritually beneficial, even virtuous.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="339" data-total-count="2887" itemprop="articleBody">“Every time that he came to rape me, he would pray,” said F, a 15-year-old girl who was captured on the shoulder of Mount Sinjar one year ago and was sold to an Iraqi fighter in his 20s. Like some others interviewed by The New York Times, she wanted to be identified only by her first initial because of the shame associated with rape.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="103" data-total-count="2990" itemprop="articleBody">“He kept telling me this is ibadah<em>,” </em>she said, using a term from Islamic scripture meaning worship.</p><figure id="media-100000003848073" class="media photo embedded layout-jumbo-horizontal media-100000003848073 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-4VS6/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-4VS6-master1050.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-4VS6/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-4VS6-master1050.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-4VS6/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-4VS6-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="A 15-year-old girl who wished to be identified only as F, right, with her father and 4-year-old brother. &ldquo;Every time that he came to rape me, he would pray,&rdquo; said F, who was captured by the Islamic State on&nbsp; Mount Sinjar one year ago and&nbsp; sold to an Iraqi fighter." data-mediaviewer-credit="Mauricio Lima for The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-4VS6/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-4VS6-master1050.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="700" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="1050" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">A 15-year-old girl who wished to be identified only as F, right, with her father and 4-year-old brother. “Every time that he came to rape me, he would pray,” said F, who was captured by the Islamic State on  Mount Sinjar one year ago and  sold to an Iraqi fighter.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Mauricio Lima for The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="314" data-total-count="3304" itemprop="articleBody">“He said that raping me is his prayer to God. I said to him, ‘What you’re doing to me is wrong, and it will not bring you closer to God.’ And he said, ‘No, it’s allowed. It’s halal,’ ” said the teenager, who escaped in April with the help of smugglers after being enslaved for nearly nine months.</p><div id="MiddleRight1" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#subhead-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><h4 id="subhead-1" class="story-subheading story-content" data-para-count="19" data-total-count="3323" itemprop="articleBody">Calculated Conquest</h4><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="225" data-total-count="3548" itemprop="articleBody">The Islamic State’s formal introduction of systematic sexual slavery dates to Aug. 3, 2014, when its fighters invaded the villages on the southern flank of Mount Sinjar, a craggy massif of dun-colored rock in northern Iraq.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="158" data-total-count="3706" itemprop="articleBody">Its valleys and ravines are home to the Yazidis, a tiny religious minority who represent less than 1.5 percent of Iraq’s estimated population of 34 million.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="261" data-total-count="3967" itemprop="articleBody">The offensive on the mountain came just two months after the fall of Mosul, the second-largest city in Iraq. At first, it appeared that the subsequent advance on the mountain was just another attempt to extend the territory controlled by Islamic State fighters.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="76" data-total-count="4043" itemprop="articleBody">Almost immediately, there were signs that their aim this time was different.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="398" data-total-count="4441" itemprop="articleBody">Survivors say that men and women were separated within the first hour of their capture. Adolescent boys were told to lift up their shirts, and if they had armpit hair, they were directed to join their older brothers and fathers. In village after village, the men and older boys were driven or marched to nearby fields, where they were forced to lie down in the dirt and sprayed with automatic fire.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="75" data-total-count="4516" itemprop="articleBody">The women, girls and children, however, were hauled off in open-bed trucks.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="393" data-total-count="4909" itemprop="articleBody">“The offensive on the mountain was as much a sexual conquest as it was for territorial gain,” said Matthew Barber, a University of Chicago expert on the Yazidi minority. He was in Dohuk, near Mount Sinjar, when the onslaught began last summer and helped create <a href="http://www.yazda.org">a foundation</a> that provides psychological support for the escapees, who number more than 2,000, according to community activists.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="312" data-total-count="5221" itemprop="articleBody">Fifteen-year-old F says her family of nine was trying to escape, speeding up mountain switchbacks, when their aging Opel overheated. She, her mother, and her sisters — 14, 7, and 4 years old — were helplessly standing by their stalled car when a convoy of heavily armed Islamic State fighters encircled them.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="268" data-total-count="5489" itemprop="articleBody">“Right away, the fighters separated the men from the women,” she said. She, her mother and sisters were first taken in trucks to the nearest town on Mount Sinjar. “There, they separated me from my mom. The young, unmarried girls were forced to get into buses.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="332" data-total-count="5821" itemprop="articleBody">The buses were white, with a painted stripe next to the word “Hajj,” suggesting that the Islamic State had commandeered Iraqi government buses used to transport pilgrims for the annual pilgrimage to Mecca. So many Yazidi women and girls were loaded inside F’s bus that they were forced to sit on each other’s laps, she said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="244" data-total-count="6065" itemprop="articleBody">Once the bus headed out, they noticed that the windows were blocked with curtains, an accouterment that appeared to have been added because the fighters planned to transport large numbers of women who were not covered in burqas or head scarves.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="341" data-total-count="6406" itemprop="articleBody">F’s account, including the physical description of the bus, the placement of the curtains and the manner in which the women were transported, is echoed by a dozen other female victims interviewed for this article. They described a similar set of circumstances even though they were kidnapped on different days and in locations miles apart.</p><figure id="media-100000003848096" class="media photo embedded layout-jumbo-horizontal media-100000003848096 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-C9CM/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-C9CM-master1050.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-C9CM/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-C9CM-master1050.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-C9CM/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-C9CM-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Sunset over Dohuk, in the Kurdistan region of northern Iraq. Islamic State militants have conquered large areas of Iraq, and the systematic rape of women and girls from the Yazidi religious minority has become deeply enmeshed in the group&amp;apos;s organization and theology." data-mediaviewer-credit="Mauricio Lima for The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-C9CM/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-C9CM-master1050.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="700" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="1050" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">Sunset over Dohuk, in the Kurdistan region of northern Iraq. Islamic State militants have conquered large areas of Iraq, and the systematic rape of women and girls from the Yazidi religious minority has become deeply enmeshed in the group&apos;s organization and theology.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Mauricio Lima for The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<div id="MiddleRight2" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-5">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="458" data-total-count="6864" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-5">F says she was driven to the Iraqi city of Mosul some six hours away, where they herded them into the Galaxy Wedding Hall. Other groups of women and girls were taken to a palace from the Saddam Hussein era, the Badoosh prison compound and the Directory of Youth building in Mosul, recent escapees said. And in addition to Mosul, women were herded into elementary schools and municipal buildings in the Iraqi towns of Tal Afar, Solah, Ba’aj and Sinjar City.</p><div id="Moses" class="ad moses-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-6">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><div class="ad mega-ad nocontent robots-nocontent">
        <div class="caption hidden">Advertisement</div><div id="MegaAd" class="mega-ad-creative"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-6">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div></div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="257" data-total-count="7121" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-6">They would be held in confinement, some for days, some for months. Then, inevitably, they were loaded into the same fleet of buses again before being sent in smaller groups to Syria or to other locations inside Iraq, where <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/video/world/middleeast/100000003226608/isis-slave-market-day.html">they were bought and sold for sex</a>.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="353" data-total-count="7474" itemprop="articleBody">“It was 100 percent preplanned,” said Khider Domle, a Yazidi community activist who maintains a detailed database of the victims. “I spoke by telephone to the first family who arrived at the Directory of Youth in Mosul, and the hall was already prepared for them. They had mattresses, plates and utensils, food and water for hundreds of people.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="135" data-total-count="7609" itemprop="articleBody">Detailed reports by <a title="Human Rights Watch report" href="https://www.hrw.org/news/2015/04/14/iraq-isis-escapees-describe-systematic-rape">Human Rights Watch</a> and <a title="Amnesty International report" href="https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2014/12/iraq-yezidi-women-and-girls-face-harrowing-sexual-violence/">Amnesty International</a> reach the same conclusion about the organized nature of the sex trade.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="105" data-total-count="7714" itemprop="articleBody">In each location, survivors say Islamic State fighters first conducted a census of their female captives.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  featured-comment-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-7">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="322" data-total-count="8036" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-7">Inside the voluminous Galaxy banquet hall, F sat on the marble floor, squeezed between other adolescent girls. In all she estimates there were over 1,300 Yazidi girls sitting, crouching, splayed out and leaning against the walls of the ballroom, a number that is confirmed by several other women held in the same location.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="252" data-total-count="8288" itemprop="articleBody">They each described how three Islamic State fighters walked in, holding a register. They told the girls to stand. Each one was instructed to state her first, middle and last name, her age, her hometown, whether she was married, and if she had children.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="166" data-total-count="8454" itemprop="articleBody">For two months, F was held inside the Galaxy hall. Then one day, they came and began removing young women. Those who refused were dragged out by their hair, she said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="291" data-total-count="8745" itemprop="articleBody">In the parking lot the same fleet of Hajj buses was waiting to take them to their next destination, said F. Along with 24 other girls and young women, the 15-year-old was driven to an army base in Iraq. It was there in the parking lot that she heard the word “sabaya<em>” </em>for the first time.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="184" data-total-count="8929" itemprop="articleBody">“They laughed and jeered at us, saying ‘You are our sabaya.’ I didn’t know what that word meant,” she said. Later on, the local Islamic State leader explained it meant slave.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="241" data-total-count="9170" itemprop="articleBody">“He told us that Taus Malik” — one of seven angels to whom the Yazidis pray — “is not God. He said that Taus Malik is the devil and that because you worship the devil, you belong to us. We can sell you and use you as we see fit.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="390" data-total-count="9560" itemprop="articleBody">The Islamic State’s sex trade appears to be based solely on enslaving women and girls from the Yazidi minority. As yet, there has been no widespread campaign aimed at enslaving women from other religious minorities, said Samer Muscati, the author of the recent Human Rights Watch report. That assertion was echoed by community leaders, government officials and other human rights workers.</p><div id="MiddleRight3" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-8">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="394" data-total-count="9954" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-8">Mr. Barber, of the University of Chicago, said that the focus on Yazidis was likely because they are seen as polytheists, with an oral tradition rather than a written scripture. In the Islamic State’s eyes that puts them on the fringe of despised unbelievers, even more than Christians and Jews, who are considered to have some limited protections under the Quran as “People of the Book.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="307" data-total-count="10261" itemprop="articleBody">In Kojo, one of the southernmost villages on Mount Sinjar and among the farthest away from escape, residents decided to stay, believing they would be treated as the <a title="NBC News report" href="http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/iraq-turmoil/has-last-christian-left-iraqi-city-mosul-after-2-000-n164856">Christians of Mosul </a>had months earlier. On Aug. 15, 2014, the Islamic State ordered the residents to report to a school in the center of town.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="202" data-total-count="10463" itemprop="articleBody">When she got there, 40-year-old Aishan Ali Saleh found a community elder negotiating with the Islamic State, asking if they could be allowed to hand over their money and gold in return for safe passage.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="156" data-total-count="10619" itemprop="articleBody">The fighters initially agreed and laid out a blanket, where Ms. Saleh placed her heart-shaped pendant and her gold rings, while the men left crumpled bills.</p><figure id="media-100000003848074" class="media photo embedded layout-jumbo-horizontal media-100000003848074 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-9KUS/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-9KUS-master1050-v5.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-9KUS/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-9KUS-master1050-v5.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-9KUS/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-9KUS-superJumbo-v5.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Aishan Ali Saleh, 40, at a refugee camp on the outskirts of Dohuk. She had lived in Kojo, one of the southernmost villages on Mount Sinjar, which was overrun by Islamic State fighters." data-mediaviewer-credit="Mauricio Lima for The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-9KUS/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-9KUS-master1050-v5.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="700" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="1050" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">Aishan Ali Saleh, 40, at a refugee camp on the outskirts of Dohuk. She had lived in Kojo, one of the southernmost villages on Mount Sinjar, which was overrun by Islamic State fighters.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Mauricio Lima for The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="88" data-total-count="10707" itemprop="articleBody">Instead of letting them go, the fighters began shoving the men outside, bound for death.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="91" data-total-count="10798" itemprop="articleBody">Sometime later, a fleet of cars arrived and the women, girls and children were driven away.</p><h4 id="subhead-2" class="story-subheading story-content" data-para-count="10" data-total-count="10808" itemprop="articleBody">The Market</h4><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="152" data-total-count="10960" itemprop="articleBody">Months later, the Islamic State made clear in its online magazine that its campaign of enslaving Yazidi women and girls had been extensively preplanned.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="262" data-total-count="11222" itemprop="articleBody">“Prior to the taking of Sinjar, Shariah students in the Islamic State were tasked to research the Yazidis,” said the English-language article, headlined “The Revival of Slavery Before the Hour,” which appeared in the October issue of the magazine, Dabiq.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="146" data-total-count="11368" itemprop="articleBody">The article made clear that for the Yazidis, there was no chance to pay a tax known as jizya to be set free, “unlike the Jews and Christians.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="303" data-total-count="11671" itemprop="articleBody">“After capture, the Yazidi women and children were then divided according to the Shariah amongst the fighters of the Islamic State who participated in the Sinjar operations, after one fifth of the slaves were transferred to the Islamic State’s authority to be divided” as spoils, the article said.</p><figure class="promo media video embedded layout-large-horizontal "
    data-videoid="100000003226608" data-media-action="modal" data-share-options-url="" data-autoplay="false" data-embedded="false"  data-adsensitivity="noads" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-9">Continue reading the main story</a>
    <span class="visually-hidden">Video</span>


    
    <figcaption class="caption">
        <h4 class="headline">ISIS ‘Slave Market Day’</h4>

                <div class="caption-video">
        
            <div class="summary-credit">
                <p class="summary">In a video posted in October 2014 on YouTube, a group of men believed to be Islamic State fighters are shown sitting in a room bantering about buying and selling Yazidi girls on “slave market day.”</p>
                <span class="credit video-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
                    By YouTube, via user BreakingNews on                                                                <span class="visually-hidden">Publish Date </span>November 14, 2014.

                    class="sharetools sharetools-video-inline"
                    data-shares="facebook|,twitter|"
                    data-url="http://www.nytimes.com/video/world/middleeast/100000003226608/isis-slave-market-day.html?action=click&amp;contentCollection=world&amp;module=embedded&amp;region=caption&amp;pgtype=article"
                    data-title="ISIS ‘Slave Market Day’"
                    data-description="In a video posted in October 2014 on YouTube, a group of men believed to be Islamic State fighters are shown sitting in a room bantering about buying and selling Yazidi girls on “slave market day.”"
                    data-content-type="video">
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
            </figcaption>
</figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="328" data-total-count="11999" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-9">In much the same way as specific Bible passages were used centuries later to support the slave trade in the United States, the Islamic State cites specific verses or stories in the Quran or else in the Sunna, the traditions based on the sayings and deeds of the Prophet Muhammad, to justify their human trafficking, experts say.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="167" data-total-count="12166" itemprop="articleBody">Scholars of Islamic theology disagree, however, on the proper interpretation of these verses, and on the divisive question of whether Islam actually sanctions slavery.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="181" data-total-count="12347" itemprop="articleBody">Many argue that slavery figures in Islamic scripture in much the same way that it figures in the Bible — as a reflection of the period in antiquity in which the religion was born.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="344" data-total-count="12691" itemprop="articleBody">“In the milieu in which the Quran arose, there was a widespread practice of men having sexual relationships with unfree women,” said Kecia Ali, an associate professor of religion at Boston University and the author of a book on slavery in early Islam. “It wasn’t a particular religious institution. It was just how people did things.”</p><div id="MiddleRight4" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-10">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="406" data-total-count="13097" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-10">Cole Bunzel, a scholar of Islamic theology at Princeton University, disagrees, pointing to the numerous references to the phrase “Those your right hand possesses” in the Quran, which for centuries has been interpreted to mean female slaves. He also points to the corpus of Islamic jurisprudence, which continues into the modern era and which he says includes detailed rules for the treatment of slaves.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="387" data-total-count="13484" itemprop="articleBody">“There is a great deal of scripture that sanctions slavery,” said Mr. Bunzel, the author of a research paper published by the Brookings Institution on the ideology of the Islamic State. “You can argue that it is no longer relevant and has fallen into abeyance. ISIS would argue that these institutions need to be revived, because that is what the Prophet and his companions did.”</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  comment-prompt-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-11">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="297" data-total-count="13781" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-11">The youngest, prettiest women and girls were bought in the first weeks after their capture. Others — especially older, married women — described how they were transported from location to location, spending months in the equivalent of human holding pens, until a prospective buyer bid on them.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  selected-comment-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-12">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="325" data-total-count="14106" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-12">Their captors appeared to have a system in place, replete with its own methodology of inventorying the women, as well as their own lexicon. Women and girls were referred to as “Sabaya,” followed by their name. Some were bought by wholesalers, who photographed and gave them numbers, to advertise them to potential buyers.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="407" data-total-count="14513" itemprop="articleBody">Osman Hassan Ali, a Yazidi businessman who has successfully smuggled out numerous Yazidi women, said he posed as a buyer in order to be sent the photographs. He shared a dozen images, each one showing a Yazidi woman sitting in a bare room on a couch, facing the camera with a blank, unsmiling expression. On the edge of the photograph is written in Arabic, “Sabaya No. 1,” “Sabaya No. 2,” and so on.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="84" data-total-count="14597" itemprop="articleBody">Buildings where the women were collected and held sometimes included a viewing room.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="197" data-total-count="14794" itemprop="articleBody">“When they put us in the building, they said we had arrived at the ‘Sabaya Market,’” said one 19-year-old victim, whose first initial is I. “I understood we were now in a slave market.”</p><figure id="media-100000003848075" class="media photo embedded layout-jumbo-horizontal media-100000003848075 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-0SJB/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-0SJB-master1050.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-0SJB/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-0SJB-master1050.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-0SJB/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-0SJB-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="A woman, who said she was raped by Islamic State militants, at a refugee camp in the Kurdistan region of northern Iraq." data-mediaviewer-credit="Mauricio Lima for The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-0SJB/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-0SJB-master1050.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="700" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="1050" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">A woman, who said she was raped by Islamic State militants, at a refugee camp in the Kurdistan region of northern Iraq.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Mauricio Lima for The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="215" data-total-count="15009" itemprop="articleBody">She estimated there were at least 500 other unmarried women and girls in the multistory building, with the youngest among them being 11. When the buyers arrived, the girls were taken one by one into a separate room.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="235" data-total-count="15244" itemprop="articleBody">“The emirs sat against the wall and called us by name. We had to sit in a chair facing them. You had to look at them, and before you went in, they took away our scarves and anything we could have used to cover ourselves,” she said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="83" data-total-count="15327" itemprop="articleBody">“When it was my turn, they made me stand four times. They made me turn around.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="319" data-total-count="15646" itemprop="articleBody">The captives were also forced to answer intimate questions, including reporting the exact date of their last menstrual cycle. They realized that the fighters were trying to determine whether they were pregnant, in keeping with a Shariah rule stating that a man cannot have intercourse with his slave if she is pregnant.</p><h4 id="subhead-3" class="story-subheading story-content" data-para-count="16" data-total-count="15662" itemprop="articleBody">Property of ISIS</h4><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="195" data-total-count="15857" itemprop="articleBody">The use of sex slavery by the Islamic State initially surprised even the group’s most ardent supporters, many of whom sparred with journalists online after the first reports of systematic rape.</p><div id="MiddleRight5" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-13">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="104" data-total-count="15961" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-13">The Islamic State’s leadership has repeatedly sought to justify the practice to its internal audience.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="268" data-total-count="16229" itemprop="articleBody">After the initial article in Dabiq in October, the issue came up in the publication again this year, in an editorial in May that expressed the writer’s hurt and dismay at the fact that some of the group’s own sympathizers had questioned the institution of slavery.</p><figure id="breaking-news-email-promo" class="interactive interactive-embedded  has-adjacency limit-small layout-small">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-14">Continue reading the main story</a>

    
    <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
            </figcaption>

        <div class="interactive-graphic">
        <!--

    </div>
    
    <div class="footer">

        
        
        
    </div>
</figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="395" data-total-count="16624" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-14">“What really alarmed me was that some of the Islamic State’s supporters started denying the matter as if the soldiers of the Khilafah had committed a mistake or evil,” the author wrote. “I write this while the letters drip of pride,’’ she said. “We have indeed raided and captured the kafirah women and drove them like sheep by the edge of the sword.” Kafirah refers to infidels.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="313" data-total-count="16937" itemprop="articleBody">In a pamphlet <a title="ISIS publication" href="http://www.memrijttm.org/islamic-state-isis-releases-pamphlet-on-female-slaves.html">published online</a> in December, the Research and Fatwa Department of the Islamic State detailed best practices, including explaining that slaves belong to the estate of the fighter who bought them and therefore can be willed to another man and disposed of just like any other property after his death.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="357" data-total-count="17294" itemprop="articleBody">Recent escapees describe an intricate bureaucracy surrounding their captivity, with their status as a slave registered in a contract. When their owner would sell them to another buyer, a new contract would be drafted, like transferring a property deed. At the same time, slaves can also be set free, and fighters are promised a heavenly reward for doing so.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="63" data-total-count="17357" itemprop="articleBody">Though rare, this has created one avenue of escape for victims.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="299" data-total-count="17656" itemprop="articleBody">A 25-year-old victim who escaped last month, identified by her first initial, A, described how one day her Libyan master handed her a laminated piece of paper. He explained that he had finished his training as a suicide bomber and was planning to blow himself up, and was therefore setting her free.</p><figure id="media-100000003848076" class="media photo embedded layout-jumbo-horizontal media-100000003848076 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-1L3O/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-1L3O-master1050.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-1L3O/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-1L3O-master1050.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-1L3O/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-1L3O-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="A woman from the village of Tojo washing dishes in a&nbsp; refugee camp in Kurdistan. She was held by the Islamic State from last August until June and says she was sexually abused." data-mediaviewer-credit="Mauricio Lima for The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-1L3O/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-1L3O-master1050.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="700" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="1050" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">A woman from the village of Tojo washing dishes in a  refugee camp in Kurdistan. She was held by the Islamic State from last August until June and says she was sexually abused.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Mauricio Lima for The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="257" data-total-count="17913" itemprop="articleBody">Labeled a “Certificate of Emancipation,” the document was signed by the judge of the western province of the Islamic State. The Yazidi woman presented it at security checkpoints as she left Syria to return to Iraq, where she rejoined her family in July.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="229" data-total-count="18142" itemprop="articleBody">The Islamic State recently made it clear that sex with Christian and Jewish women captured in battle is also permissible, according to a new 34-page manual issued this summer by the terror group’s Research and Fatwa Department.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="477" data-total-count="18619" itemprop="articleBody">Just about the only prohibition is having sex with a pregnant slave, and the manual describes how an owner must wait for a female captive to have her menstruating cycle, in order to “make sure there is nothing in her womb,” before having intercourse with her. Of the 21 women and girls interviewed for this article, among the only ones who had not been raped were the women who were already pregnant at the moment of their capture, as well as those who were past menopause.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="358" data-total-count="18977" itemprop="articleBody">Beyond that, there appears to be no bounds to what is sexually permissible. Child rape is explicitly condoned: “It is permissible to have intercourse with the female slave who hasn’t reached puberty, if she is fit for intercourse,” according to a translation by the Middle East Media Research Institute of a pamphlet published on Twitter last December.</p><figure id="media-100000003848078" class="media photo embedded layout-large-horizontal media-100000003848078 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-MUDG/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-MUDG-articleLarge.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-MUDG/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-MUDG-articleLarge.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-MUDG/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-MUDG-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="A 25-year-old Yazidi woman showed a&nbsp;&ldquo;Certificate of Emancipation&rdquo; given to her by a Libyan who had enslaved her. He explained that he had finished his training as a suicide bomber and was planning to blow himself up, and was therefore setting her free." data-mediaviewer-credit="Mauricio Lima for The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/08/13/world/middleeast/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-MUDG/20150813-ISISSLAVE-slide-MUDG-articleLarge.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="400" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="600" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">A 25-year-old Yazidi woman showed a “Certificate of Emancipation” given to her by a Libyan who had enslaved her. He explained that he had finished his training as a suicide bomber and was planning to blow himself up, and was therefore setting her free.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Mauricio Lima for The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<div id="MiddleRight6" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-15">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
    	<div id="MiddleRightN" class="ad text-ad middle-right-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-15">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="262" data-total-count="19239" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-15">One 34-year-old Yazidi woman, who was bought and repeatedly raped by a Saudi fighter in the Syrian city of Shadadi, described how she fared better than the second slave in the household — a 12-year-old girl who was raped for days on end despite heavy bleeding.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="218" data-total-count="19457" itemprop="articleBody">“He destroyed her body. She was badly infected. The fighter kept coming and asking me, ‘Why does she smell so bad?’ And I said, she has an infection on the inside, you need to take care of her,” the woman said.</p><button class="button comments-button  theme-speech-bubble" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-16">
</button>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="107" data-total-count="19564" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-16">Unmoved, he ignored the girl’s agony, continuing the ritual of praying before and after raping the child.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="201" data-total-count="19765" itemprop="articleBody">“I said to him, ‘She’s just a little girl,’ ” the older woman recalled. “And he answered: ‘No. She’s not a little girl. She’s a slave. And she knows exactly how to have sex.’ ’’</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="51" data-total-count="19816" itemprop="articleBody">“And having sex with her pleases God,” he said.</p>
        
                                <div id="addendums" class="addendums">
    <div class="story-addendum story-content theme-correction">
        <strong> Correction: August 13, 2015 </strong> <br/>
    	An earlier version of this article misstated the location of Matthew Barber when the invasion of Mount Sinjar began in August 2014. He was in Dohuk, near Mount Sinjar, not on the mountain itself.    </div>
    <div class="story-addendum story-content theme-correction">
        <strong> Correction: August 25, 2015 </strong> <br/>
    	<p>Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 14 about the Islamic State&rsquo;s codification of sexual slavery in the regions of Iraq and Syria that it has conquered referred incorrectly to the author of an editorial in Dabiq, the group&rsquo;s online magazine, that lamented the fact that some ISIS sympathizers were questioning the institution of slavery. The author, who was not named, is a woman.</p>    </div>
</div>
        <footer class="story-footer story-content">
    <div class="story-meta">

    text-decoration: none;
}
#nyt-button-sub a:hover {
    background-color: #326891;
    border: 1px solid #265E8B;
    text-decoration: none;
}
#hovercard {
    width: 450px;
    height: 328px;
    display:none;
    margin-left: -360px;
    z-index: 1000000152;
    background-color:#fff;
    border: 0;
    position:absolute;
    left: 77%;
    top: 30px;
    text-align:left;
    -moz-box-shadow: 0 0 5px #888;
    -webkit-box-shadow: 0 0 5px #888;
    box-shadow: 0 0 5px #888;
    white-space: normal;
}

#hovercard img {
     width: 450px;
     height: 328px;
}
#hovercard:after {
        bottom: 100%;
	left: 350px;
	border: solid transparent;
	content: " ";
	width: 0;
	height: 0;
	position: absolute;
	pointer-events: none;
	border-bottom-color: #2e2e2e;
	border-width: 8px;
	margin: 0;
}
.NYT5Style #hovercard {
        top: 18px;
}
.NYT5Style #hovercard  a:hover {
  background-color: #414042;
}

  #hovercard {
    top: 31px !important;
  }

    top: 28px !important;
    margin-left: -283px;
  }

<div class="columnGroup first">				
<h1 itemprop="headline"  class="articleHeadline"><NYT_HEADLINE  version="1.0" type=" ">Chasing the Higgs</NYT_HEADLINE></h1>     <div class="articleSpanImage"><div id="articleSpanVideoModule" class="articleSpanVideoModule">
<div id="articleSpanVid_100000002094542" class="articleSpanVideo">
<script type="text/javascript">
(function() {
    var NYTD_videoMetaData = {
        videoId: "100000002094542",
        socialUrl: "http://www.nytimes.com/video/science/100000002094542/higgs-boson-a-cern-collision-course.html",
        parentSection: "science",
        stillOverlay: "http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2013/03/05/science/higgs-video-replace/higgs-video-replace-articleLarge-v2.jpg"    };
    if (NYTD.ArticleSpan && NYTD.ArticleSpan.ArticleSpanVideo) {
        NYTD.ArticleSpan.ArticleSpanVideo.prepareVideoModule(NYTD_videoMetaData);
    }
})();
</script>
</div><div id="articleSpanVideoByline" class="byline" style="display:none;">By Jeffery DelViscio, Catherine Spangler and Soo-Jeong Kang</div>
<div id="articleSpanVideoPhotoCredit" class="credit">Denis Balibouse/Reuters</div>
<p id="articleSpanVideoCaption" class="caption"><strong class="videoIcon video">Collision Course:</strong> 
It was the longest, most costly manhunt in science for an elusive particle that was said to be key to the workings of the universe. For a generation of physicists, it was an appointment with history.</p>
</div>
</div> <!--[if lt IE 8]>
    <script type="text/javascript">
        if($$('div.articleSpanImage') != null) {
            var articleSpanImage = $$('div.articleSpanImage')[0].getElementsByTagName("img")[0];
            var articleSpanImageSrc = articleSpanImage.getAttribute('src');
            articleSpanImage.setAttribute('src',"http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/global/backgrounds/transparentBG.gif");
            var filter = "progId:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.AlphaImageLoader(src='"+articleSpanImageSrc+"', sizingMethod='scale' )";
            articleSpanImage.style.filter = filter;
        }
    </script>
<![endif]--> 
<NYT_BYLINE >
<h6 class="byline">By 
<span itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person" itemid="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/o/dennis_overbye/index.html">
<a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/o/dennis_overbye/index.html" rel="author" title="More Articles by DENNIS OVERBYE"><span itemprop="name">DENNIS OVERBYE</span></a></span></h6>
</NYT_BYLINE>
<h6 class="dateline">Published: March 4, 2013    </h6>
<div class="shareTools shareToolsThemeClassic articleShareToolsTop"
	data-shares="facebook,twitter,google,save,email,showall|Share,print,singlepage,reprints,ad" 
	data-title="Chasing the Higgs" 
	data-url="http://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/05/science/chasing-the-higgs-boson-how-2-teams-of-rivals-at-CERN-searched-for-physics-most-elusive-particle.html" 
	data-description="At the Large Hadron Collider near Geneva, two armies of physicists struggled to close in on the Higgs boson, the Great White Whale of modern science."></div>
<meta name="emailThisHash" content="peaTgVsklV1bx0vgs5xwJg">
<div class="articleBody">
<span itemprop="copyrightHolder provider sourceOrganization" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Organization" itemid="http://www.nytimes.com">

</NYT_CORRECTION_TOP>
    <p itemprop="articleBody">
Meyrin, Switzerland — Vivek Sharma missed his daughter.        </p>

<div class="icon enlargeThis"><a href="javascript:pop_me_up2('http://www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2013/03/05/science/05HIGG3.html','05HIGG3_html','width=471,height=630,scrollbars=yes,toolbars=no,resizable=yes')">Enlarge This Image</a></div>
<a href="javascript:pop_me_up2('http://www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2013/03/05/science/05HIGG3.html','05HIGG3_html','width=471,height=630,scrollbars=yes,toolbars=no,resizable=yes')">
<span itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2013/03/05/science/05HIGG3/05HIGG3-articleInline.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject">
<img itemprop="url" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2013/03/05/science/05HIGG3/05HIGG3-articleInline.jpg" width="190" height="237" alt="">
<meta itemprop="identifier" content="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2013/03/05/science/05HIGG3/05HIGG3-articleInline.jpg" />
<meta itemprop="height" content="190" />
<meta itemprop="width" content="237" />
<meta itemprop="copyrightHolder" content="Sean McCabe/Photographs by David Ahntholz and Michal Czerwonka for The New York Times" />
</span>
</a>
</div>
<h6 class="credit">Sean McCabe/Photographs by David Ahntholz and Michal Czerwonka for The New York Times</h6>
<p class="caption">Vivek Sharma, left, who coordinated for the CMS team, and an Atlas counterpart, Eilam Gross. The two teams were intended to complement and challenge each other.                            </p>
</div>
  
</div>
<div id="readerscomment" class="inlineLeft"></div>
<div class="articleBody">
 <p itemprop="articleBody">
<a title="More about Professor Sharma." href="http://vsharma.ucsd.edu/">A professor</a> at the University of California, San Diego, Dr. Sharma had to spend months at a time away from home, coordinating a team of physicists at the <a title="The Web site of the Large Hadron Collider." href="http://public.web.cern.ch/public/en/lhc/lhc-en.html">Large Hadron Collider</a>, here just outside Geneva. But on April 15, 2011, Meera Sharma’s 7th birthday, he flew to California for some much-needed family time. “We had a fine birthday, a beautiful day,” he recalled.        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
Then Dr. Sharma was alerted to a blog post. There it was reported that a rival team of physicists had beaten his team to the discovery of the <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/subjects/h/higgs_boson/index.html?inline=nyt-classifier" title="Recent and archival news about Higgs boson." class="meta-classifier">Higgs boson</a> — the long-sought “God particle.”        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
If his rivals were right, it would mean a cascade of <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/news/science/topics/nobel_prizes/index.html?inline=nyt-classifier" title="More articles about Nobel Prizes." class="meta-classifier">Nobel Prizes</a> flowing in the wrong direction and, even more vexingly, that Dr. Sharma and his colleagues had missed one of nature’s clues and thus one of its greatest prizes; that the dream of any physicist — to know something that nobody else has ever known — was happening to someone else.        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
He flew back to Geneva the next day. “My wife was stunned,” he recalled.        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
He would not see them again for months.        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
Dr. Sharma and his colleagues had every reason to believe that they were closing in on the Great White Whale of modern science: the Higgs boson, a particle whose existence would explain all the others then known and how they fit together into the jigsaw puzzle of reality.        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
For almost half a century, physicists had chased its quantum ghost through labyrinths of mathematics and logic, and through tons of electronics at powerful particle colliders, all to no avail.        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
Now it had come down to the Large Hadron Collider, where <a title="Times article: A Giant Takes on the Biggest Questions in Physics." href="http://www.nytimes.com/2007/05/15/science/15cern.html">two armies of physicists</a>, each 3,000 strong, struggled against each other and against nature, in a friendly but deadly serious competition.        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
In physics tradition, they were there to check and complement each other in a $10 billion experiment too valuable to trust to only one group, no matter how brilliant and highly motivated.        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
The stakes were more than just Nobel Prizes, bragging rights or just another quirkily named addition to the zoo of elementary particles that make up nature at its core. The Higgs boson would be the only visible manifestation of the Harry Potterish notion put forward back in 1964 (most notably by Peter Higgs of the University of Edinburgh) that there is a <a title="Times article on Harvards Lisa Randall explaining the Higgs boson." href="http://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/12/science/physicists-anxiously-await-news-of-the-god-particle.html">secret, invisible force field</a> running the universe. (The other theorists were François Englert and Robert Brout, both of Université Libre de Bruxelles; and Tom Kibble of Imperial College, London, Carl R. Hagen of the University of Rochester and Gerald Guralnik of Brown University.)        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
Elementary particles — the electrons and other subatomic riffraff running around in our DNA and our iPhones — would get their masses from interacting with this field, the way politicians draw succor from cheers and handshakes at the rope line.        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
Without this mystery field, everything in the universe would be pretty much the same, a bland fizz of particles running around at the speed of light. With it, there could be atoms and stars, and us.        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
Leon Lederman, the former director of the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, or Fermilab, in Illinois, where the boson was being sought, once called it <a title="Leon Ledermans book, The God Particle" href="http://books.google.com/books/about/The_God_Particle.html?id=-v84Bp-LNNIC">“the God particle,”</a> scandalizing his colleagues but <a title="Times essay on the &quot;God Particle&quot; " href="http://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/07/science/07essa.html">delighting journalists</a>, who kept using the name. Dr. Lederman later said that he wanted to call it the “goddamn particle.”        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
The “Easter Bump Hunt” of April 2011, as it came to be called, was only one episode in a roller coaster of sleepless nights, bright promises, missed clues, false alarms, euphoria, depression, gritty calculation, cooperation and envy, all the tedium and vertiginous notions of modern science.        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
On the way to fulfill what they thought was their generation’s rendezvous with scientific destiny, the physicists dangled from harnesses in hard hats to construct detectors bigger than apartment buildings in underground caverns. They strung wires and cranked bolts to coax thousand-ton magnets to less than a thousandth of an inch of where they needed to be. They wrote millions of lines of code to calibrate and run devices that would make NASA engineers stand by the track with their hats in their hands in admiration.        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
In their down time, they proposed marriage and <a title="Video of the LHC Rap." href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j50ZssEojtM">made rap videos</a> in the tunnels where subatomic particles collided. They ate, slept and partied, threw snowballs and worried that an unguarded smile in the cafeteria or a glance at a friend’s laptop could bias a half-billion-dollar experiment or give away cosmic secrets.        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
Maria Spiropulu, a professor at the California Institute of Technology, put it this way in an e-mail, “The experiments are very large collaborations and they have the good, the bad, the crooks, the Sopranos, the opportunists — a prototype of the world as we know it.”        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
<strong>August 2010</strong>        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
<strong>Promised Fireballs</strong>        </p><p itemprop="articleBody">
Everybody agreed that the Large Hadron Collider was the last stand in the hunt for the Higgs boson. Circling for 17 miles underneath the complex of aging postwar buildings outside Geneva (and out into France) that constitute the <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/organizations/c/cern/index.html?inline=nyt-org" title="More articles about CERN." class="meta-org">European Organization for Nuclear Research</a>, or CERN, the collider was designed to accelerate the subatomic particles known as protons to more than 99 percent of the speed of light — an energy of seven trillion electron volts — and crash them together.        </p>
         <noscript>
             <img src="http://meter-svc.nytimes.com/meter.gif"/>
         </noscript>

<p>This article has been revised to reflect the following correction:</p><p><strong>Correction: March 5, 2013</strong></p><p><p>Because of an editing error, an earlier version of a photo caption with this article misstated the temperature of the cooling system around the accelerator ring at CERN. It is –456 degrees Fahrenheit, not –520 degrees.</p></p><p>This article has been revised to reflect the following correction:</p><p><strong>Correction: March 8, 2013</strong></p><p><p>An article on Tuesday about the search for the Higgs boson misidentified, at one point, the group for which a physicist, Vivek Sharma, works. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, Dr. Sharma works for CMS, not for Atlas.</p></p>	
</div>

<h6 class="kicker">Punched Out</h6>
<h1 itemprop="headline"  class="articleHeadline"><NYT_HEADLINE  version="1.0" type=" ">Derek Boogaard: A Boy Learns to Brawl</NYT_HEADLINE></h1>     <div class="articleSpanImage">											<script>
											NYTD.NYTMM.Boogaard.articleSpan();

<NYT_BYLINE >
<h6 class="byline">By 
<span itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person" itemid="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/b/john_branch/index.html">
<a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/b/john_branch/index.html" rel="author" title="More Articles by JOHN BRANCH"><span itemprop="name">JOHN BRANCH</span></a></span></h6>
</NYT_BYLINE>
<h6 class="dateline">Published: December 3, 2011    </h6>
<div class="shareTools shareToolsThemeClassic articleShareToolsTop"
	data-shares="facebook,twitter,google,save,email,showall|Share,print,singlepage,reprints,ad" 
	data-title="Derek Boogaard: A Boy Learns to Brawl" 
	data-url="http://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/04/sports/hockey/derek-boogaard-a-boy-learns-to-brawl.html" 
	data-description="Over six months, The Times examined the life and death of the hockey player Derek Boogaard. The first article of a three-part series revisits his childhood and his progression from boy to brawler."></div>
<meta name="emailThisHash" content="Ht8nGMnSNbz44TEvbk1v2A">
<div class="articleBody">
<span itemprop="copyrightHolder provider sourceOrganization" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Organization" itemid="http://www.nytimes.com">
<meta itemprop="name" content="The New York Times Company"/>
<meta itemprop="url" content="http://www.nytco.com/"/>
<meta itemprop="tickerSymbol" content="NYSE NYT"/>
</span>
<meta itemprop="copyrightYear" content="2011"/>












<NYT_TEXT >

<NYT_CORRECTION_TOP>
</NYT_CORRECTION_TOP>
    <p itemprop="articleBody">
DEREK BOOGAARD was scared. He did not know whom he would fight, just that he must.        </p> 
</div>
<div class="articleInline runaroundLeft">
  
<!--forceinline-->  
<div class="columnGroup doubleRule"><h4>Punched Out, Part 1</h4><div class="story"><p class="summary">Over six months, The New York Times examined the life and death of the professional hockey player Derek Boogaard, who rose to fame as one of the sport's most feared fighters before dying at age 28 on May 13.</p>
<p class="summary">This article, the first of a three-part series, revisits Boogaard's childhood in the rugged youth and junior leagues of western Canada and his progression from physically awkward boy to renowned brawler on the ice.</p></div></div>
<div class="columnGroup doubleRule">    </div></div>            <script type="text/javascript">
        if (typeof NYTDVideoManager != "undefined") {
            NYTDVideoManager.setAllowMultiPlayback(false);
        }
        
        function displayCompanionBanners(banners, tracking) {
            tmDisplayBanner(banners, "videoAdContent", 300, 250, null, tracking);
        }
        </script>

<div class="articleInline runaroundLeft"><div class="articleInline runaroundLeft"></div>
<div class="doubleRule"><h3 class="sectionHeader">National Hockey League</h3>

</ul>
