<div id="main">
<div id="interactiveShell">
<div class="columnGroup firstColumnGroup">
<div class="ledeStory">
<div class="module insetHFullWidth">
<div class="shareTools shareToolsThemeClassic shareToolsThemeClassicHorizontal interactive970ShareTools"
	data-shares="facebook,twitter,google,email,showall|Share" 
	data-title="Wal-Mart Abroad" 
	data-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/business/walmart-bribery-abroad-series.html" 
	data-description="How a retail giant fueled growth with bribes"></div>
<meta name="emailThisHash" content="FnemrLkj2y9IyoPJvW4D5A">
<div class="storyHeader">
<h1>Wal-Mart Abroad</h1>
</div><!--close .storyHeader -->
<div class="storySummary">
<span class="summary">How a retail giant fueled growth with bribes</span>
</div><!--close .storySummary -->
</div><!--end .module insetHFullWidth -->
<div id="interactiveFreeFormMain">
<!--<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="http://mmstorage.nyhq.nytint.com/bundler/?action=bundle&staging=true&files=projects/2012/MexicoLanding/MexicoLanding.css" />-->
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/css/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/MexicoLanding.css" />
<div id="nytmm_walmart">
<div id="nytmm_walmart_header">
<div id="nytmm_walmart_title"></div>
<div id="nytmm_walmart_summary"></div>
</div><!--END HEADER-->
<div id="nytmm_walmart_left">
<div id="nytmm_walmart_left_lead">
<!--news box for award info-->
<div id="nytmm_walmart_news_box">
<p>This series won <a href="http://www.pulitzer.org/citation/2013-Investigative-Reporting" target="_blank">a Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting</a> on April 15, 2013.</p>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_walmart_lead_image">
<img width="396" height="264" src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/world/201204_INV_MEXICO/lead/mexico-lead-1.jpg">
<div class="credit">Josh Haner/The New York Times</div>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_walmart_headline"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/22/business/at-wal-mart-in-mexico-a-bribe-inquiry-silenced.html">Vast Mexico Bribery Case Hushed Up by Wal-Mart After Top-Level Struggle</a></div>
<div class="nytmm_walmart_related_summary">
<div class="nytmm_walmart_related_meta">
<span class="byline">By <span class="author"><a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/b/david_barstow/index.html">David Barstow</a></span></span><br />
<span class="pubdate">Published: April 21, 2012</span>
</div>
<p>Confronted with evidence of widespread corruption in Mexico, top Wal-Mart executives focused more on damage control than on rooting out wrongdoing, an examination by The New York Times found.</p></div>
<div id="nytmm_walmart_related_response">
<div class="caption">In Mexico, Wal-Mart advertises its stores on green signs, a color usually reserved for street signs nationwide.</div>
<a class="nytmm_lightbox" id="doc-walmart">
<div class="nytmm_related_response_thumb"><img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/world/201204_INV_MEXICO/response-ss.jpg" /><div class="nytmm_document magnify"></div></div>
<div class="nytmm_related_response_summary">
<p class="title">Wal-Mart&rsquo;s Response</p></a>
<p>David W. Tovar, a spokesman for Wal-Mart, responds to The New York Times.</p></div>
</div>
<div class="clear"></div>
</div>
<div id="nytmm_walmart_left_secondary" class="clearfix">
<!--CUT SECONDARY CODE GOES HERE-->
<div id="nytmm_walmart_map_box">
<div class="column-series">
<div class="g-series-header">
<h3>Four Bribes, One Wal-Mart</h3>
<p>Wal-Mart de Mexico faced a series of legal obstacles in its quest to build a supermarket in the protected archaeological zone around the pyramid complex in Teotihuac&aacute;n. It overcame those obstacles by authorizing bribes, records and interviews show.</p>
</div>
<div class="g-graphic-inline clearfix" id="g-graphic-zoning">
<div class="g-map-container">
<div id="g-zoning-map">
<div id="g-zoning-map-altered"><img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/MexicoArticle2/map-zoning-altered.png" width="334" height="154" /></div>
<div id="g-zoning-map-original"><img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/MexicoArticle2/map-zoning-original.png" width="334" height="154" /></div>
</div>
<div class="g-map-caption" id="g-zoning-caption">
<b></b>
<span class="g-original">In the original map, the plot&rsquo;s zoning designation, H500A, allowed only houses to be built there.</span>
<span class="g-altered">In the altered map, the land where Wal-Mart wanted to build had its zoning changed to E-T-M, a category that permitted a supermarket.</span>
</div>
</div>
<h4><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/18/business/walmart-bribes-teotihuacan.html#zoning-bribes">Zoning Bribe: $52,000</a></h4>
<p>The biggest hurdle was Teotihuac&aacute;n&rsquo;s zoning map. It clearly prohibited commercial development where Wal-Mart wanted to build. Wal-Mart de Mexico authorized a $52,000 bribe payment to have the map altered, records and interviews show.</p>
<div class="g-btn" id="g-zoning-btn">Show the <span class="g-original">altered</span><span class="g-altered">original</span> map</div>
</div>
<div class="g-graphic-container clearfix">
<div class="g-graphic-inline" id="g-graphic-traffic">
<h4><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/18/business/walmart-bribes-teotihuacan.html#traffic-bribes">Traffic Bribe: $25,900</a></h4>
<p>Wal-Mart wanted to build by the main entrance into Teotihuac&aacute;n, in a spot already choked with traffic. Wal-Mart de Mexico authorized a $25,900 bribe payment to gain the approval of local traffic authorities, records and interviews show.</p>
</div>
<div class="g-graphic-inline" id="g-graphic-landmark">
<h4><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/18/business/walmart-bribes-teotihuacan.html#landmark-bribes">Archaeology Bribe: Up to $81,000</a></h4>
<p>Wal-Mart could not build by the pyramids without a permit from the agency that protects Mexico&rsquo;s cultural landmarks. Wal-Mart de Mexico offered a &ldquo;donation&rdquo; of up to $45,000 and a &ldquo;personal gift&rdquo; of up to $36,000 in exchange for the permit, records and interviews show.</p>
</div>
</div>
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/MexicoArticle2/map-full-series.jpg" width="537" height="209" class="g-series-map" />
<div class="g-graphic-inline" id="g-graphic-political">
<h4><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/18/business/walmart-bribes-teotihuacan.html#political-bribes">Political Bribe: $114,000</a></h4>
<p>Facing certain opposition from local merchants and residents, Wal-Mart de Mexico executives agreed to pay $114,000 in bribes to guarantee the support of Teotihuac&aacute;n&rsquo;s mayor and his allies on the municipal council, records and interviews show.</p>
</div>
<div class="clear"></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div><!--END LEFT SIDE-->
<div id="nytmm_walmart_right">
<div id="nytmm_walmart_right_top">
<div id="nytmm_walmart_right_lead">
<div class="nytmm_walmart_headline"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/18/business/walmart-bribes-teotihuacan.html">The Bribery Aisle: How Wal-Mart Got Its Way in Mexico</a></div>
<div class="nytmm_walmart_related_meta">
<span class="byline">By <span class="author"><a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/b/david_barstow/index.html">David Barstow</a></span> and <span class="author">ALEJANDRA XANIC von BERTRAB</span></span><br />
<span class="pubdate">Published: December 18, 2012</span>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_walmart_related_summary">Wal-Mart de Mexico was an aggressive and creative corrupter, offering large payoffs to get what the law otherwise prohibited, an examination by The New York Times found.</div>
</div>
<div id="nytmm_walmart_right_video">
<div class="nytmm_lightbox" id="preview-video">
<img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/MexicoArticle2/landing-video-cover.jpg" />
<div class="nytmm_play magnify"></div>
</div>
<p class="summary">A preview of a New York Times investigation revealing bribery by Wal-Mart as it sought to build in the shadow of one of Mexico&rsquo;s most revered cultural landmarks, the pyramids of Teotihuac&aacute;n.</p>
</div>
<div id="nytmm_walmart_right_media">
<div class="nytmm_walmart_right_thumb"><img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/images/multimedia/bundles/projects/2012/MexicoArticle2/landing-vignette-cover.jpg" /></div>
<div class="nytmm_walmart_right_headlines">
<p><a class="nytmm_lightbox video" id="emma-video" title="Emma Protest Vignette" data-src="100000001950829" data-caption="The pyramids of Teotihuacan are one of Mexico\'s most revered cultural landmarks. When Wal-Mart de Mexico began building nearby, residents such as Emma Ortega staged protests and hunger strikes." rel="address:/emma-video">A Leader in the Protests Against Wal-Mart</a></p>
<p><a class="nytmm_lightbox slideshow" id="pyramid-slideshow" title="Teo Slideshow" data-src="http://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2012/12/16/world/americas/Walmart.slideshow.jsonp" data-caption="Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Proin vitae felis felis, vitae vulputate sapien. Vestibulum fringilla laoreet purus." rel="address:/pyramid-slideshow">Wal-Mart and the Pyramids</a></p>
</div>
<div class="clear"></div>
</div>
</div>
<div id="nytmm_walmart_right_related">
<div class="nytmm_walmart_section">
<h3>Featured Stories</h3>
<div class="nytmm_walmart_related">
<div class="nytmm_walmart_related_headline"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/30/business/wal-mart-bribery-scandal-complicates-us-expansion-plans.html">Wal-Mart Bribery Scandal Complicates U.S. Expansion Plans</a></div>
<div class="nytmm_walmart_related_meta">
<span class="byline">By <span class="author">STEPHANIE CLIFFORD</span> and <span class="author">STEVEN GREENHOUSE</span></span><br />
<span class="pubdate">Published: April 29, 2012</span>
</div>
<div class="nytmm_walmart_related_thumb"><img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/images/2012/04/30/business/jp-walmart/jp-walmart-thumbStandard.jpg"></div>
<div class="nytmm_walmart_related_summary">In the week after bribery allegations were made public by The New York Times, Wal-Mart projects in Los Angeles, Brooklyn, San Diego and Boston are facing tighter scrutiny and challenges.</div>
</div><!--END RELATED 1-->
</div><!--END SECTION 1-->

                    <div class="column">
                        <h3 class="menu-heading">News</h3>

  }
  .NYT5Style #hovercard {
    top: 28px !important;
    margin-left: -283px;
  }
  .NYT5Style #hovercard:after {
    left: 273px;
  }
}
/* EXCLUDING NYT4 INTERACTIVES */
#interactiveABC #bar1-singlepanel {
   display: none;
}
</style>

<h2>

                <h2 class="kicker interactive-kicker">
                                        <span class="kicker-label">

                                    <h1 class="story-heading interactive-headline" itemprop="headline">Times Coverage of Ebola: Pulitzer-Winning Articles and More</h1>
            
            <div class="story-meta-footer interactive-meta-footer">
                                 <p class="interactive-leadin summary">

  width: auto;

  margin-bottom: 15px;

}
.viewport-medium .list_items.feature .listy_subhead, .list_items.feature .listy_subhead {
  font-size: 13px;
  margin-bottom: 10px;

<div class='introduction'>
<div class='listy_body'>
<p>The Ebola epidemic in West Africa has been the worst in history, claiming more than 10,000 lives. To convey the scale of the outbreak, The Times has mobilized dozens of reporters, photographers, video journalists and others over the last year, producing more than 400 articles, including about 50 front-page articles from inside the Ebola-afflicted countries. Following is a sample of their work.</p>
</div>
</div>
<ol class='feature list_items no_numbers' data-display-style='feature' data-number-style='no_numbers'>
<li class='row list_item clearfix ' id='id-552ffa8d3632390001010000'>
<figure class='media photo ' data-media-action='modal'>
<span class='visually-hidden'>
Photo
</span>
<div class='image'>
<img alt='' class='media-viewer-candidate' data-mediaviewer-caption='Mark Jerry, sick with Ebola, initially maintained denials about the illnesses that ravaged his family.' data-mediaviewer-credit='Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times' data-mediaviewer-src='' data-pattern='http://i1.nyt.com/images/2014/11/13/world/africa/20141114-FAMILY-slide-WCAB/20141114-FAMILY-slide-WCAB-jumbo-v4.jpg' data-widths='[{"slug":"master1050","size":1050},{"slug":"master180","size":180},{"slug":"blog225","size":225},{"slug":"tmagSF","size":362},{"slug":"blog427","size":427},{"slug":"blog480","size":480},{"slug":"master495","size":495},{"slug":"blog533","size":533},{"slug":"tmagArticle","size":592},{"slug":"articleLarge","size":600},{"slug":"master675","size":675},{"slug":"jumbo","size":1024},{"slug":"popup","size":650},{"slug":"slide","size":600},{"slug":"superJumbo","size":2048}]' src='http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png'>

<div class='listy_kicker'>
NOV. 13, 2014
</div>
<div class='listy_headline'>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/14/world/africa/in-ebola-outbreak-in-liberia-a-familys-strength-can-be-its-fatal-flaw.html">For a Liberian Family, Ebola Turns Loving Care Into Deadly Risk</a>
</div>
<div class='listy_subhead'>
By NORIMITSU ONISHI
</div>
<div class='listy_body'>
<p>The Doryen family, unbowed survivors of Liberia’s civil war, saw seven members die from the virus in a matter of months and lost its sense of unity.</p>
</div>
</li>

<div class='listy_kicker'>
OCT. 4, 2014
</div>
<div class='listy_headline'>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/05/world/africa/ebolas-cultural-casualty-hugs-in-hands-on-liberia.html">Ebola’s Cultural Casualty: Hugs in Hands-On Liberia</a>
</div>
<div class='listy_subhead'>
By HELENE COOPER
</div>
<div class='listy_body'>
<p>As Ebola ravages West Africa, Liberians are losing an integral part of their culture, in which the double-cheek kiss was once the standard greeting.</p>
</div>

<div class='listy_kicker'>
AUG. 23, 2014
</div>
<div class='listy_headline'>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/24/world/africa/sierra-leone-if-they-survive-in-ebola-ward-they-work-on.html">Those Who Serve Ebola Victims Soldier On</a>
</div>
<div class='listy_subhead'>
By ADAM NOSSITER and BEN C. SOLOMON
</div>
<div class='listy_body'>
<p>In the battle against Ebola, the front line is stitched together not only by doctors and nurses, but also by janitors, drivers and body handlers whose work puts their lives at risk.</p>
</div>
</li>
<li class='row list_item clearfix ' id='id-55300f096533640001020000'>

OCT. 16, 2014

<div class='listy_headline'>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/17/world/africa/because-of-ebola-ambulance-work-in-liberia-is-a-busy-and-lonely-business.html"> Ambulance Work in Liberia Is a Busy and Lonely Business</a>
</div>
<div class='listy_subhead'>
By BEN C. SOLOMON
</div>
<div class='listy_body'>
<p>Only about 15 ambulance teams are available to aid Monrovia, a city of nearly 1.5 million people, where hundreds of new Ebola cases are reported each week.</p>
</div>

</div>
<div class='listy_headline'>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/30/health/how-ebola-roared-back.html">How Ebola Roared Back</a>
</div>
<div class='listy_subhead'>
By KEVIN SACK, SHERI FINK, PAM BELLUCK and ADAM NOSSITER
</div>
<div class='listy_body'>
<p>For a fleeting moment last spring, the epidemic sweeping West Africa might have been stopped. But the opportunity to control the virus, which has now caused more than 7,800 deaths, was lost.</p>
</div>
</li>
<li class='row list_item clearfix ' id='id-553010fb3632320001000000'>

<div class='listy_headline'>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/02/world/africa/ebola-spreading-in-west-africa.html"> A Hospital From Hell, in a City Swamped by Ebola</a>
</div>
<div class='listy_subhead'>
By ADAM NOSSITER
</div>
<div class='listy_body'>
<p>Ebola is sweeping into areas of West Africa that had been largely spared the onslaught. The consequences in one Sierra Leone hospital have been devastating.</p>
</div>

<span class='visually-hidden'>

</span>
Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
</span>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<div class='listy_kicker'>
SEPT. 13, 2014
</div>
<div class='listy_headline'>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/14/world/africa/ebola-liberia.html">Back to the Slums of His Youth, to Defuse the Ebola Time Bomb</a>
</div>
<div class='listy_subhead'>
By NORIMITSU ONISHI
</div>
<div class='listy_body'>
<p>Liberia remains desperately short on everything needed to halt the spread of Ebola, but an epidemiologist is working block by block to fill a crucial need: the support of residents.</p>
</div>
</li>
<li class='row list_item clearfix ' id='id-553504bf3265660001000000'>
<figure class='media photo horizontal' data-media-action='modal'>
<span class='visually-hidden'>
Photo
</span>
<div class='image'>
<img alt='' class='media-viewer-candidate' data-mediaviewer-caption='Chernoh Alpha Bah in Freetown, Sierra Leone, on Friday. Medical supplies that Mr. Bah shipped to Sierra Leone to help fight Ebola have sat in a shipping container for almost two months.' data-mediaviewer-credit='Samuel Aranda for The New York Times' data-mediaviewer-src='http://i1.nyt.com/images/2014/10/06/world/africa/LEONE/LEONE-superJumbo.jpg' data-pattern='http://i1.nyt.com/images/2014/10/06/world/africa/LEONE/LEONE-{{size}}.jpg' data-ratio='0.6669921875' data-widths='[{"slug":"master1050","size":1050},{"slug":"master180","size":180},{"slug":"blog225","size":225},{"slug":"tmagSF","size":362},{"slug":"blog427","size":427},{"slug":"blog480","size":480},{"slug":"master495","size":495},{"slug":"blog533","size":533},{"slug":"tmagArticle","size":592},{"slug":"articleLarge","size":600},{"slug":"master675","size":675},{"slug":"jumbo","size":1024},{"slug":"popup","size":650},{"slug":"slide","size":600},{"slug":"superJumbo","size":2048}]' src='http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png'>
<div class='media-action-overlay'>
<i class='icon'></i>
</div>
</div>
<figcaption class='caption'>
<span class='caption-text'>
Chernoh Alpha Bah in Freetown, Sierra Leone, on Friday. Medical supplies that Mr. Bah shipped to Sierra Leone to help fight Ebola have sat in a shipping container for almost two months.
</span>
<span class='credit'>
<span class='visually-hidden'>
Credit
</span>
Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
</span>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<div class='listy_kicker'>
OCT. 5, 2014
</div>
<div class='listy_headline'>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/06/world/africa/sierra-leone-ebola-medical-supplies-delayed-docks.html">Ebola Help for Sierra Leone Is Nearby, but Delayed on the Docks</a>
</div>
<div class='listy_subhead'>
By ADAM NOSSITER
</div>
<div class='listy_body'>
<p>More than $140,000 worth of medical supplies have been locked inside a dented container at the port in Freetown, Sierra Leone, since Aug. 9.</p>
</div>
</li>
<li class='row list_item clearfix ' id='id-553507d43265660001010000'>
<figure class='media photo horizontal' data-media-action='modal'>
<span class='visually-hidden'>
Photo
</span>
<div class='image'>
<img alt='' class='media-viewer-candidate' data-mediaviewer-caption='Relatives of a man who died of what appeared to be Ebola waited outside their home in Monrovia while a team of workers sprayed and disinfected the area.' data-mediaviewer-credit='Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times' data-mediaviewer-src='http://i1.nyt.com/images/2014/09/04/world/JP-WHO-2/JP-WHO-2-superJumbo.jpg' data-pattern='http://i1.nyt.com/images/2014/09/04/world/JP-WHO-2/JP-WHO-2-{{size}}.jpg' data-ratio='0.6689453125' data-widths='[{"slug":"master1050","size":1050},{"slug":"master180","size":180},{"slug":"blog225","size":225},{"slug":"tmagSF","size":362},{"slug":"blog427","size":427},{"slug":"blog480","size":480},{"slug":"master495","size":495},{"slug":"blog533","size":533},{"slug":"tmagArticle","size":592},{"slug":"articleLarge","size":600},{"slug":"master675","size":675},{"slug":"jumbo","size":1024},{"slug":"popup","size":650},{"slug":"slide","size":600},{"slug":"superJumbo","size":2048}]' src='http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png'>
<div class='media-action-overlay'>
<i class='icon'></i>
</div>
</div>
<figcaption class='caption'>
<span class='caption-text'>
Relatives of a man who died of what appeared to be Ebola waited outside their home in Monrovia while a team of workers sprayed and disinfected the area.
</span>
<span class='credit'>
<span class='visually-hidden'>
Credit
</span>
Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
</span>
</figcaption>
</figure>
<div class='listy_kicker'>
SEPT. 3, 2014
</div>
<div class='listy_headline'>
<a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/04/world/africa/cuts-at-who-hurt-response-to-ebola-crisis.html">Cuts at W.H.O. Hurt Response to Ebola Crisis</a>
</div>
<div class='listy_subhead'>
By SHERI FINK
</div>
<div class='listy_body'>
<p>The epidemic has exposed gaping holes in the ability to tackle outbreaks in an increasingly interconnected world, where diseases can quickly spread from remote villages to cities housing millions of people.</p>
</div>
</li>
</ol>

var googletag = googletag || {};
googletag.cmd = googletag.cmd || [];
(function (){
    window.advBidxc = window.advBidxc || {};
    window.advBidxc.renderAd = function (){};
    window.advBidxc.startTime = new Date().getTime();
    function loadScript(tagSrc) {
        if (tagSrc.substr(0, 4) !== 'http') {
            var isSSL = 'https:' == document.location.protocol;
            tagSrc = (isSSL ? 'https:' : 'http:') + tagSrc;
        }   
        var scriptTag = document.createElement('script'),
            placeTag = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
        scriptTag.type = 'text/javascript';
        scriptTag.async = true;
        scriptTag.src = tagSrc;
        placeTag.parentNode.insertBefore(scriptTag, placeTag);
    }
    function loadGPT(){
        if(!window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded){
            loadScript('//www.googletagservices.com/tag/js/gpt.js');
            window.advBidxc.isAdServerLoaded = true;
        }
    }

    window.advBidxc.loadGPT = loadGPT;
    setTimeout(window.advBidxc.loadGPT,PREBID_TIMEOUT);// Timeout in case of loading error

})();

        <p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="651" data-total-count="651" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-1"><span class="dropcap">O</span>n the morning of his wedding, in 1956, Henry Frye realized that he had a few hours to spare before the afternoon ceremony. He was staying at his parents’ house in Ellerbe, N.C.; the ceremony would take place 75 miles away, in Greensboro, the hometown of his fiancée; and the drive wouldn’t take long. Frye, who had always been practical, had a practical thought: Now might be a good time to finally register to vote. He was 24 and had just returned from Korea, where he served as an Air Force officer, but he was also a black man in the American South, so he wasn’t entirely surprised when his efforts at the registrar’s office were blocked.</p><aside class="marginalia collection-marginalia collection collection-type-column collection-tone-feature collection-section-magazine collection-theme-latest-headlines nocontent robots-nocontent" role="complementary">
    <div class="nocontent robots-nocontent">
                <header>
                        <div class="collection-meta">
                <div class="follow-button-placeholder" data-collection-id="column.disenfranchised"></div>
                <h2 class="collection-marginalia-heading"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/column/disenfranchised">Disenfranchised</a></h2>
                <h3 class="collection-marginalia-subheading">A series examining the ongoing effort to roll back the protections of the Voting Rights Act.</h3>
            </div>
        </header>
        <ul>
                        <li><article class="story theme-summary">
    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/17/magazine/this-looks-like-a-national-strategy.html?rref=collection%2Fcolumn%2FDisenfranchised">
        <h2 class="story-heading">
            <span class="story-heading-text">
                                ‘This Looks Like a National Strategy’            </span>
            <time class="dateline" datetime="2015-08-17">AUG 17</time>
        </h2>
    </a>
</article>
</li>
                        <li><article class="story theme-summary">
    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/12/magazine/nine-years-ago-republicans-favored-voting-rights-what-happened.html?rref=collection%2Fcolumn%2FDisenfranchised">
        <h2 class="story-heading">
            <span class="story-heading-text">
                                Nine Years Ago, Republicans Favored Voting Rights. What Happened?            </span>
            <time class="dateline" datetime="2015-08-12">AUG 12</time>
        </h2>
    </a>
</article>
</li>
                        <li><article class="story theme-summary">
    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/06/magazine/the-speech-that-defined-the-fight-for-voting-rights-in-congress.html?rref=collection%2Fcolumn%2FDisenfranchised">
        <h2 class="story-heading">
            <span class="story-heading-text">
                                The Speech That Defined the Fight for Voting Rights in Congress            </span>
            <time class="dateline" datetime="2015-08-06">AUG 6</time>
        </h2>
    </a>
</article>
</li>
                        <li><article class="story theme-summary">
    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/04/magazine/whats-left-of-the-voting-rights-act.html?rref=collection%2Fcolumn%2FDisenfranchised">
        <h2 class="story-heading">
            <span class="story-heading-text">
                                What’s Left of the Voting Rights Act?            </span>
            <time class="dateline" datetime="2015-08-05">AUG 5</time>
        </h2>
    </a>
</article>
</li>
                        <li><article class="story theme-summary">
    <a class="story-link" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/31/magazine/why-republicans-should-worry-about-restrictive-voting-laws.html?rref=collection%2Fcolumn%2FDisenfranchised">
        <h2 class="story-heading">
            <span class="story-heading-text">
                                Why Republicans Should Worry About Restrictive Voting Laws            </span>
            <time class="dateline" datetime="2015-07-31">JUL 31</time>
        </h2>
    </a>
</article>
</li>
                    </ul>
        <footer>
            <p class="user-action"><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/column/disenfranchised">See More &raquo;</a></p>
        </footer>
    </div><!-- close nocontent -->
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="902" data-total-count="1553" itemprop="articleBody">Adopting a tactic common in the Jim Crow South, the registrar subjected Frye to what election officials called a literacy test. In 1900, North Carolina voters amended the state’s Constitution to require that all new voters “be able to read and write any section of the Constitution in the English language,” but for decades some registrars had been applying that already broad mandate even more aggressively, targeting perfectly literate black registrants with arbitrary and obscure queries, like which president served when or who had the ultimate power to adjourn Congress. “I said, ‘Well, I don’t know why are you asking me all of these questions,’ ” Frye, now 83, recalled. “We went around and around, and he said, ‘Are you going to answer these questions?’ and I said, ‘No, I’m not going to try.’ And he said, ‘Well, then, you’re not going to register today.’ ”</p><aside id='middle-right-paid-post-container' class='ad middle-right-ad paid-post-ad hidden nocontent robots-nocontent'>
                                <h2 class='marginalia-heading'></h2>
                                    <ul class='story-menu'>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost1' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost2' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost3' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                        <li id='MiddleRightPaidPost4' class='story-menu-item ad'></li>
                                    </ul>

<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="315" data-total-count="1868" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-3">Sitting with me on the enclosed porch of his red-brick ranch house in Greensboro, drinking his wife’s sweet tea, Frye could joke about the exchange now, but at the time it left him upset and determined. When he met Shirley at the altar, the first thing he said was: “You know they wouldn’t let me register?”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="48" data-total-count="1916" itemprop="articleBody">“Can we talk about this later?” she replied.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="362" data-total-count="2278" itemprop="articleBody">After a few weeks, Frye drove over to the Board of Elections in Rockingham, the county seat, to complain. An official told him to go back and try again. This time a different registrar, after asking if he was the fellow who had gone over to the election board, handed him a paragraph to copy from the Constitution. He copied it, and with that, he became a voter.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="891" data-total-count="3169" itemprop="articleBody">But in the American South in 1956, not every would-be black voter was an Air Force officer with the wherewithal to call on the local election board; for decades, most had found it effectively impossible to attain the most elemental rights of citizenship. Only about one-quarter of eligible black voters in the South were registered that year, according to the limited records available. By 1959, when Frye went on to become one of the first black graduates of the University of North Carolina law school, that number had changed little. When Frye became a legal adviser to the students running the antisegregation sit-ins at the Greensboro Woolworth’s in 1960, the number remained roughly the same. And when Frye became a deputy United States attorney in the Kennedy administration, it had grown only slightly. By law, the franchise extended to black voters; in practice, it often did not.</p><div id="MiddleRight1" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-4">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="1229" data-total-count="4398" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-4">What changed this state of affairs was the passage, 50 years ago this month, of the Voting Rights Act. Signed on Aug. 6, 1965, it was meant to correct “a clear and simple wrong,” as Lyndon Johnson said. “Millions of Americans are denied the right to vote because of their color. This law will ensure them the right to vote.” It eliminated literacy tests and other Jim Crow tactics, and — in a key provision called Section 5 — required North Carolina and six other states with histories of black disenfranchisement to submit any future change in statewide voting law, no matter how small, for approval by federal authorities in Washington. No longer would the states be able to invent clever new ways to suppress the vote. Johnson called the legislation “one of the most monumental laws in the entire history of American freedom,” and not without justification. By 1968, just three years after the Voting Rights Act became law, black registration had increased substantially across the South, to 62 percent. Frye himself became a beneficiary of the act that same year when, after a close election, he became the first black state representative to serve in the North Carolina General Assembly since Reconstruction.</p><figure id="media-100000003819077" class="media photo embedded has-adjacency layout-large-vertical media-100000003819077" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/07/29/magazine/civil-rights-portraits-slide-9S8G/civil-rights-portraits-slide-9S8G-blog427.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/07/29/magazine/civil-rights-portraits-slide-9S8G/civil-rights-portraits-slide-9S8G-blog427.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/07/29/magazine/civil-rights-portraits-slide-9S8G/civil-rights-portraits-slide-9S8G-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="&lt;strong&gt;Henry Frye &lt;/strong&gt;| The first black chief justice of the North Carolina Supreme Court, Frye, 83, was prevented by a Jim Crow literacy test from registering to vote on his wedding day in 1956." data-mediaviewer-credit="Jeremy M. Lange for The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/07/29/magazine/civil-rights-portraits-slide-9S8G/civil-rights-portraits-slide-9S8G-blog427.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="558" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="427" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text"><strong>Henry Frye </strong>| The first black chief justice of the North Carolina Supreme Court, Frye, 83, was prevented by a Jim Crow literacy test from registering to vote on his wedding day in 1956.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Jeremy M. Lange for The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="768" data-total-count="5166" itemprop="articleBody">In the decades that followed, Frye and hundreds of other new black legislators built on the promise of the Voting Rights Act, not just easing access to the ballot but finding ways to actively encourage voting, with new state laws allowing people to register at the Department of Motor Vehicles and public-assistance offices; to register and vote on the same day; to have ballots count even when filed in the wrong precinct; to vote by mail; and, perhaps most significant, to vote weeks before Election Day. All of those advances were protected by the Voting Rights Act, and they helped black registration increase steadily. In 2008, for the first time, black turnout was nearly equal to white turnout, and Barack Obama was elected the nation’s first black president.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="861" data-total-count="6027" itemprop="articleBody">Since then, however, the legal trend has abruptly reversed. In 2010, Republicans flipped control of 11 state legislatures and, raising the specter of voter fraud, began undoing much of the work of Frye and subsequent generations of state legislators. They rolled back early voting, eliminated same-day registration, disqualified ballots filed outside home precincts and created new demands for photo ID at polling places. In 2013, the Supreme Court, in the case of <a href="http://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/12pdf/12-96_6k47.pdf">Shelby County v. Holder</a>, directly countermanded the Section 5 authority of the Justice Department to dispute any of these changes in the states Section 5 covered. Chief Justice John Roberts Jr., writing for the majority, declared that the Voting Rights Act had done its job, and it was time to move on. Republican state legislators proceeded with a new round of even more restrictive voting laws.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="912" data-total-count="6939" itemprop="articleBody">All of these seemingly sudden changes were a result of a little-known part of the American civil rights story. It involves a largely Republican countermovement of ideologues and partisan operatives who, from the moment the Voting Rights Act became law, methodically set out to undercut or dismantle its most important requirements. The story of that decades-long battle over the iconic law’s tenets and effects has rarely been told, but in July many of its veteran warriors met in a North Carolina courthouse to argue the legality of a new state voting law that the Brennan Center for Justice at the New York University Law School has called one of the “<a href="http://www.brennancenter.org/sites/default/files/analysis/Voting_Laws_Roundup_2013.pdf">most restrictive since the Jim Crow era</a>.” The decision, which is expected later this year, could determine whether the civil rights movement’s signature achievement is still justified 50 years after its signing, or if the movement itself is finished.</p><div id="Moses" class="ad moses-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#subhead-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><div class="ad mega-ad nocontent robots-nocontent">
        <div class="caption hidden">Advertisement</div><div id="MegaAd" class="mega-ad-creative"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#subhead-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div></div><div id="MiddleRight2" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#subhead-1">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><h4 id="subhead-1" class="story-subheading story-content" data-para-count="12" data-total-count="6951" itemprop="articleBody"><em>I. 1865-1980</em></h4><h4 id="subhead-2" class="story-subheading story-content" data-para-count="25" data-total-count="6976" itemprop="articleBody">1. “States’ rights”</h4><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="635" data-total-count="7611" itemprop="articleBody">The fundamental promise of American democracy is that every citizen gets a vote, but delivering the franchise from on high and in the face of violent local opposition has always been a complicated legal proposition. The 13th Amendment freed the slaves, and the 14th Amendment gave them citizenship. But the key to Reconstruction was the 15th Amendment, ratified in 1870, which did something far more radical, not just guaranteeing (male) former slaves the right to vote but giving Congress the authority to enforce that right state by state, an authority that to this day many legislators see as a drastic intrusion into local affairs.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="435" data-total-count="8046" itemprop="articleBody">The new laws immediately enfranchised more than 700,000 black Southerners. Although blacks made up just 13 percent of the overall United States population, they made up 36 percent of the South’s population and a much higher percentage in some states, including a majority in Mississippi and South Carolina. Their enfranchisement was a shock to the political system that almost exclusively benefited Republicans, the party of Lincoln.</p><figure id="voting-rights-timeline-pre-vra" class="interactive interactive-embedded  limit-small layout-sub-medium">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-5">Continue reading the main story</a>

    
    <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
            <h2 class="interactive-headline">
            A Brief History of the Black Vote (Up to the Voting Rights Act)        </h2>
            </figcaption>

        <div class="interactive-graphic">
        <!--

-->
